title: How do I answer an MC 012 form received in the mail? I am the defendant, I owe a balance can only afford to pay a certain amount
question: It was a car repossession, there was a wage garnishment at one time, but I changed employers. I'd rather pay without my wages been garnished. I did speak with the attorney on the case and I let them know I could pay a certain amount comfortably monthly. I was told they would get back with me shortly. In the mean time, there is possible bank levy and I am considering filing bankruptcy. I would appreciate any general information.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Wage garnishment,Property repossession,Bankruptcy and debt,Filing a lawsuit,Sued for debt
answers: You understand that because you did not respond to the court summons, or if you did respond, you did not show up in court for the trial, the court entered a judgment against you. If you believe that you were not properly served with summons, you should make a motion to set aside the judgment. Your first step should be to get a copy of relevant documents from the court file, especially including the Proof of Service. Then, contact an attorney who regularly represents consumers in debt collection cases.

Have all the proper notices been sent to you by the finance company/creditor, following repo? See my Avvo legal guide, linked below. Hire an experienced debt collection DEFENSE attorney, so that you can avoid bankruptcy and defend against this case. There are deadlines, such as the 30 day deadline to respond to a personally served lawsuit in Superior Court, so do not delay, it may take time for the lawyer to review the documentation and facts to prepare a proper response to assert your rights.

Yes. You must file Answer or risk default. You may also contact creditor and try to work out payment arrangements and avoid litigation, judgment, garnishment.
Personal BK may be best option. Consult BK counsel.
If you can't pay what's owed, bankruptcy is your best option.
